fields.description:
After setting up OAuth, connecting directly to our GitHub organization (containing our "golden" repositories), only shows the public repositories. This is with the OAuth set up properly with the Organization being the owner of the Application connection on the GitHub side. From our side, it appears that the problem is directly related to the repositories being owned by an organization, rather than by a specific user. 

Connecting to a specific user in the organization that has full admin rights to the entire organization will show any private forks of those same repositories, but the actual master repositories are not shown (only the forks). I have tried with the OAuth Application setup in GitHub being owned by the Organization and being owned by the user with full admin rights to the organization, neither works - both exhibit the same behavior. 

There is a thread in Atlassian Answers that has gone unanswered, with other people reporting the same behavior: https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/68418/connecting-to-my-github-organization-only-shows-the-public-repos
fields.summary: GitHub private repositories owned by an Organization not showing

However, if we create a commit including the tag "#comment" on a branch and then merge that commit into a second branch, then all of our issues are updated with the "#comment" flag during the merge commit. Need a way to prevent the same commit from updating the issue twice.

fields.description:
Using WebHooks, I have observed a reproducible issue using JIRA and Bitbucket (both Atlassian cloud hosted).

The fix for un-sync'd DVCS repos (found at http://bit.ly/1NNEYgj) suggests using a POST service from Bitbucket, however, the lastest Atlassian Cloud indicates that Webhooks are now preferred, and POST service will be deprecated.

Following the "POST Service" method with Bitbucket works as follows:
* Create an issue in JIRA with default status of "To-Do"
* Also create a branch for this issue in a linked Bitbucket repository (no probelms there)
* Create a Bitbucket POST service with the following:
*     "https://<my site>.atlassian.net/rest/bitbucket/1.0/repository/<repo id>/sync"
* Create a smart commit with #In-Progress to update the issue status
* Navigate to JIRA issue
* Observe that everything is immediately updated: the dev panel, the status ("In-Progress")

However, when I attempt to do the exact same procedure using a webhook instead, I find something ODD occurring:
* Repeat steps exactly as above, but create Bitbucket WebHook instead of POST service
* Navigate to JIRA issue
*     Observe that nothing is updated, and the commit is not seen
* Navigate to JIRA "DVCS Accounts" page
*     Hover over the "Sync Repo" circular icon
*     Observe the timestamp indicating that the repo successfully sync'd at the correct time
*     However, how could this be? The DVCS page says the repo DID sync, as it was told to. Yet the issue page does not reflect the update. 

So my question becomes, how can a DVCS repo sync via a WebHook, but not actually update Project issues to reflect commits and dev activity?

And why would this differ between using WebHooks vs POST Service?
fields.summary: DVCS Accounts page shows timestamp for potentially failed sync

** Auto Link New Repositories: - Checked

When you make the connection, it will stack trace instead of providing useful feedback (ie. a 404). Furthermore, it will create the connection anyway, with the invalid name as a linked heading with no repositories.

fields.description:
h3. Summary
The first commit of a newly created repository on Bitbucket sets the "_SMARTCOMMIT\_AVAILABLE_" flag to "f", which makes the smart commit fail on JIRA.
h3. Environment
JIRA Cloud
Affected version is 5.0.0-D20160601T054537

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Have JIRA Cloud and Bitbucket integrated
# Create an empty repository on Bitbucket
# Clone it with _git clone_ to your machine
# Add a file/folder to it
# Commit the changes making sure you add a message that references an existing JIRA issue and use "_#comment_" smart commit (Ex: {{git commit -m "ABC-123 #comment This is a comment."}})
# Push the changes with {{git push}}

h3. Expected Results
On JIRA you can see the comment added to the ABC-123 issue
h3. Actual Results
The comment isn't added.
 
h3. Notes
Checking JIRA's database you can see the "_SMARTCOMMIT\_AVAILABLE_" flag is set to "f" instead of "t" as it should because a smart commit was performed (see the _MESSAGE_ column).

---------+-----------------------+--------+---------------------+------------+------------+-------------------+----+-----------+-------------------------------------------------------------+------------
------------------------------+--------------+-------------+--------------------------------------------------+------------------------------------------+---------------+-----------------------+--------
-

09f67d0f217e292e1acef4fdf7efc | []           |             | Felipe van Schaik Willig <fwillig@atlassian.com> | 5e3c0fc07e309f67d0f217e292e1acef4fdf7efc |             0 | f                     |       3

Add the comment manually to the JIRA issue, or only add comments from the second commit on.

fields.description:
Here is a description on how DVCS connector synchronises BB/GH commits with JIRA issue.
* Initially after linking new repository to JIRA we use BB/GH API to retrieve ALL commits in the repository. 
* After this initial synchronisation connector does only INCREMENTAL synchronisation - it retrieves only changesets that were commited after the last synchronisation. 
* To find out which changesets to retrieve, connector remembers the changeset with latest date and keeps the date in LAST_COMMIT_DATE variable. When doing incremental synchronisation we ask BB/GH api to return latest changesets and use only those where commit date of changeset is >= LAST_COMMIT_DATE.

This way if JIRA is down for some time, users can continue commiting. When JIRA goes back up, connector retrieves all the commits from latest up to LAST_COMMIT_DATE.

The problem with this approach is when users don't push their commits immediately:
* Let's say on Tuesday *userA* commits and pushes his commit 
* DVCS Connector will catch and synchronise the commit and set LAST_COMMIT_DAY to Tuesday
* On Wednesday *userB* pushes his commit that was commited on Monday. The commit date for this commit is Monday.
* DVCS Connector will never synchronise the commit because commit date (Monday) < LAST_COMMIT_DATE


REST API differences
Bitbucket and GitHub APIs behave differently and different approaches will have to be used to fix it.

GitHub
GitHub API (https://api.github.com/repos/jirabitbucketconnector/missingcommits/commits) returns changesets ordered by commitDate. Changeset for each branch have to be retrieved separately.

Bitbucket
Bitbucket API (https://api.bitbucket.org/1.0/repositories/jirabitbucketconnector/missingcommits/changesets) returns changeset ordered by push date. All changesets from all branches are returned from same REST call.

fields.description:
This happens after we changed from {{select("ID,*")}} to {{select()}} in DCON-468.

The {{AO.stream}} method would only select the "ID" column and fail to lazily load the other columns when given a query with {{select()}}.

To fix this, either use {{find}} or explicitly specify the columns in {{select("columns")}}.

There are multiple places that use {{AO.stream}} but all of them uses only the "ID" column, except for the {{SmarcommitOperation}} class.

Smart commit processing will fail with the following message:
{noformat}
2014-10-02 17:47:36,415 DVCSConnector.SmartCommitsProcessor:thread-2 WARN admin 1049x1700x1 1yahiq0 0:0:0:0:0:0:0:1 /rest/bitbucket/1.0/repository/21/softsync [plugins.dvcs.smartcommits.SmartcommitOperation] Failed to process smartcommit operation. Cause = class java.lang.NullPointerException : null
{noformat}

This is because the {{getMessage()}} call returns null and {{parseCommitComment}} would throw npe when processing the message.

This affects JIRA 6.3.7, which has DVCS Connector 2.1.23.
fields.summary: Smart commits are not processed

fields.description:
The DVCS connector uses the custom regex matching linker with Bitbucket. This works, but is case sensitive (BB-12345 would match when bb-12345 wouldn't).

Bitbucket also has a Jira linker which should just handle the case sensitivity just fine.

So, it would be great if either the regex was modified to be case insensitive or the Jira linker was used.
fields.summary: Linkers on Bitbucket are case sensitive

fields.summary: DVCS Repositories tab (under Admin -> Plugins -> Source Control) throws a Postgres Exception

fields.description: Oauth should be spelled as OAuth, with A in upper case.
fields.summary: Typo: GitHub Oauth settings page

fields.description:
Whenever a commit is logged in BitBucket or GitHub the DVCS connector doesn't trigger the smart commits such as #resolve #comment ..etc I have tested most of them and it doesn't work since the deployment of version 1.1.

Example commit that I have tested:
- SEC-2 #time 2d 5h #comment Task completed ahead of schedule #resolve
- SEC-2 #resolve #comment test resolve
- SEC-2 #resolve test resolve
fields.summary: Git Smart Commits doesn't work since the OnDemand 174

fields.description:
Commit messages with {{#time}} create multiple time logs on the Jira issue if they also appear in merge commit messages.

Similar issue filed against Bitbucket Server: [STASH-3529|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/STASH-3529]


Date: 11-Nov-2020
Issue re-appearing on Bitbucket cloud.
Steps to reproduce:
# Create remote branch: bugfix/ASD-123
# Push a new commit to the new branch with commit message: ASD-123 #comment Fixed multiple parses #time 1h'
# Switch to main branch and make a new commit.
# Push the commit to remote main branch.
# Rebase branch bugfix/ASD-123 onto main
# Push --force onto origin bugfix/ASD-123
# Verify Jira issue ASD-123 which now contain 2 comment and 2h time
# Create a pull request to merge ASD-123 to main branch with squash merge option.
# Verify Jira issue ASD-123 which now contain 3 comment and 3h time


Expected behaviour:
Only 1h should be logged against ASD-123
fields.summary: Merge commit messages result in duplicate time entries in Jira when using Smart Commits

fields.description:
h3. ***Current Behavior***
Newly created users do not receive BitBucket invites when automatic access is configured.

h3. ***Expected Behavior***
Newly created users receives BitBucket invites when automatic access is configured.

h3. ***Steps to Reproduce***
# Log into JIRA as a user with administrative rights.
# Navigate to the JIRA Admin pages.
# Choose DVCS Accounts from the Add-ons section.
# The Manage DVCS Accounts page displays. 
# Locate the account to configure.
# Press the settings  icon and choose Configure automatic access from the menu. The Configure automatic access dialog appears. It lists the groups for the Bitbucket account.
# Select the groups you want new users assigned to.
# Press Save.
# Create a new user in JIRA

fields.description:
After I click Post Commit, the "Add Post-Receive" appears. Two issues here:

1. The position it is displayed is not ideal and we should move it to either right after the repository for which I clicked "Post Commit" or the bottom of the page. Right now, it's nested between the intro text about adding a repo" and the repo config UIs.
2. Shouldn't the title "Add the Post-Receive Hook" use the same colour as the "Add additional GitHub repositories"? The current title style makes the title itself too obscure to be spotted.
fields.summary: reposition the "Post-Receive Hook" area

fields.summary: javascript null object error on create bitbucket connection page on IE8

fields.description: When attempting to add a Github repository, the organization owner generated the oauth key and secret.  The JIRA administrator was able to use the oauth key, secret, and the authorized Github user with owner privileges. The JIRA administrator is provided a authorization token.  The Github owner who is also a jira-developer can use the authorization token to log into their Github account which then forwards to JIRA to complete the authorization cycle.  However, when the Github owner uses their JIRA credentials to complete the authorization, he is presented with an error saying he does not have permission to access the page.  As far as I can tell you must be both an Github owner and a JIRA administrator to link via the DVCS plugin.  We have several working linked accounts however they were all made by having both Github owner and JIRA administrator permissions.  How is the linkage accomplished if you don't have privileges in both places.
fields.summary: Owner of Github repository unable to use auth token in Jira unless administrator

fields.description: We have a project that has the key P4F and any commits to it with the Github connector does not work. I tried with a dummy project that has key TEST and it works fine. From the documentations the format has to be 2 upper case characters but it should also work for any alpha numeric characters as well.  We don't want to change our keys as we would have to back up all of our data and change xmls around, and then change the db reference to reference the new project.
fields.summary: Smart Commits do not work when Project has numeric characters in key

Should Replace the !default.jsp with /default.jsp

fields.description:
We use Jira Agile OnDemand and have BitBucket repos.

We use Smart commits in our Commit comments, eg

MYISSUE-5 #comment This is a comment #time 1h

In the last week or so I have noticed that Jira Agile is no longer applying #time references in the commit messages, hence not applying any Worklogs to and Jira issues (see attached image)

This is affecting our timesheet tracking and worklogs.

What is the problem?
fields.summary: Smart commits #time tracking does not work
Concurrent Operations not working

fields.description:
h4. Scenario:
* OnDemand customer using SVN+FeCru
* Makes use of [smart commits|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/AOD/Processing+JIRA+issues+with+commit+messages] to add comments to issues through commit messages
* Wants to migrate to Bitbucket due to [FishEye OnDemand end-of-life|http://go-dvcs.atlassian.com/display/EOL/Source+Review+Bundle+End+of+Service]
* Follows the instructions we provide at http://go-dvcs.atlassian.com/display/aod/Migrating+from+Subversion+to+Git+on+Bitbucket

h4. Problem:
When they successfully migrate to Bitbucket and the DVCS Connector synchronises with their migrated repos for the first time, it will re-process those smart commits again. This means they will get duplicate comments added to their existing JIRA issues. This could potentially be worse than extra comments -- it could be extra work logged or a re-opened issue being closed again.
fields.summary: Migrating from OnDemand's SVN+FeCru to Bitbucket+DVCS Connector can result in duplicated entities from smart commits

fields.description:
It's not possible to link to repositories using the JIRA DVCS Connector plugin 0.30 on Internet Explorer 8.

Steps to produce:

When we click on *link repository* it says connecting, then nothing happens. The JIRA DVCS plugin version 0.30 works on IE9, chrome, FireFox , but does not work on IE8.

Cheers
fields.summary: Unable to link repositories using Internet Explorer 8, for the new JIRA DVCS connector plugin 0.30

fields.description:
Hi,
I have installed JIRA 6.0.3 and tried to sync GitHub using the DVCS Connector. Ther very first sync worked very well, however, if I try to sync my repo manually I get the following error message:
{code}
  Sync Failed: There was a SQL exception thrown by the Active Objects library: Database: - name:Microsoft SQL Server - version:10.00.1600 - minor version:0 - major version:10 Driver: - name:jTDS Type 4 JDBC Driver for MS SQL Server and Sybase - version:1.2.4 java.sql.SQLException: Invalid column name *.   –  
{code}

I already tried the instructions [here | https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRAKB/JIRA+DVCS+Plugin+Install+Fails+after+Upgrade], but the problem keeps happening.

How can I get the repo to sync from now?

Thanks for your help,
fields.summary: Sync Failed - Invalid column name" *

fields.description: Also applies for the success message.

fields.description:
Hi,
  I'm getting this error when the DVCS commits are presented in Jira

Can't find JIRA user with given author email: alex@macheen.com

I know my email is setup properly in JIRA and there's a registered user with this email. Can you take a look? 

Thanks,
fields.summary: Can't find JIRA user with given author email
BitBucket configuration page does not use AUI for error messages.

fields.description:
The DVCS connector is generating a lot of "changeset created" events on some JIRA instances (presumably ones with large repositories).

When the DVCS connector tries to read the events from the sync events table this causes an OOME.
fields.summary: DVCS connector EventService causing OutOfMemoryError

fields.description:
Hello,
One of our clients is using JIRA 6 and DVCS 1.3.1.1. Recently, we've been having stability issues with the DVCS plugin.
Basically, here is what is happening:
1. DVCS generates a SQL Query on the database
2. This query, for some reason, gets "stuck" and therefore blocks all the following queries
3. This makes the DB Connection Pool quickly full and eventually JIRA crashes.

Since I've deactivated DVCS the issue didn't happen again, that is why I believe the root-cause is the DVCS plugin. The SQL query that *always* blocks all the others is the following:
{code}
SELECT * FROM jiraschema.AO_E8B6CC_CHANGESET_MAPPING WHERE SMARTCOMMIT_AVAILABLE =  @P0   ORDER BY DATE DESC
{code}

We are using JIRA 6.0.3 and DVCS 1.3.1.1 and SQL Server 10.50.4000 database.

Can you please let me know how this can be fixed? 
Also, I wanted to upgrade to 1.4.0.1 to see if it would fix the issue, but I cannot do that because of DCON-330.

Thanks for your help,
fields.summary: SQL query keeps blocking all the others

fields.description:
h3. ***Current Behavior***
Newly created users do not receive BitBucket invites when automatic access is configured.

h3. ***Expected Behavior***
Newly created users receives BitBucket invites when automatic access is configured.

h3. ***Steps to Reproduce***
# Log into JIRA as a user with administrative rights.
# Navigate to the JIRA Admin pages.
# Choose DVCS Accounts from the Add-ons section.
# The Manage DVCS Accounts page displays. 
# Locate the account to configure.
# Press the settings  icon and choose Configure automatic access from the menu. The Configure automatic access dialog appears. It lists the groups for the Bitbucket account.
# Select the groups you want new users assigned to.
# Press Save.
# Create a new user in JIRA
fields.summary: Configure Automatic Team Invites is not Functioning

fields.description:
The fix introduced for DCON-190 changed the where clause in a way that breaks PostgreSQL databases.

A proper fix to this issue involves not performing the query *at all* if the project in question has no repository mappings. We should *not* be issuing a database query that we know will return zero rows in the first place.

Our GitHub account is structured such that all repos are owned by our GitHub organization, within our GitHub organization we have created GitHub Teams which have varying levels of access to different repos within our AwesomeCo organization.  Logically, users are assigned to one or more GitHub Teams within our GitHub Organization.

fields.description:
The manual sync function under DVCS account didn't perform the smart commit feature in the commit message and just rather include the latest commit message. However, the smart commit feature did processed when it run by the scheduler which default set to run at every hour.

The only workaround at the moment was to reduce the scheduler under services section to trigger at few minutes once so that the smart commit are process more frequent as it is somehow annoy to see that the issue not being process some time after the developer committed.
fields.summary: DVCS manual sync doesn't process smart commit

fields.description:
When using the #time smart commit directive: https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BITBUCKET/Processing+JIRA+issues+with+commit+messages 

Awesome feature! But...If you include decimal values as part of a commit message to Bitbucket, such as “#time 1.5h”, the time worked gets parsed incorrectly into JIRA.

Commit with "#time 1.5h" and JIRA logs 5 hours of work with “.1 “ prepended to the commit comment in the work log. Yes, you read this right – it not only loses the decimal value, it reverses it in the process. So a 1.5 hours logged becomes 5 hours logged.

The work-around is either use a whole value (“#time 90m”) or provide the value in parts (“#time 1h 30m”).

On the positive side, my coworkers have been impressed with my 24+ hour workdays (that is until we figured out the issue ;-)
fields.summary: Smart commit #time with decimal values parses incorrectly

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Software Cloud*. Using *JIRA Software Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSWSERVER-14061].
  {panel}

When a synchronization takes a long time to run in {{RepositoryServiceImpl.syncRepositoryList}}, it occupies the {{SYNC_REPOSITORY_LIST_LOCK}} for synching repositories (for all organizations). This would block subsequent syncs that need to enter the same code block, even for syncs for other organizations.

One example of the long running-ness is due to a long running SELECT query in DCON-425.

This issue could cause all (the four) clustered scheduler threads to be used up by the DVCS Connector, thus no other clustered scheduled tasks could be run.

There are a few things to improve here:
# The sync should be moved outside of the scheduler thread
#* The scheduler thread should be just kicking off the sync and immediately return to free up the thread for other scheduler jobs.
# The {{SYNC_REPOSITORY_LIST_LOCK}} is too exclusive.
#* It could be applied to per organization, instead of to the whole DB
# The attempt to lock should timeout, once we change the lock to be per org
#* When the lock is occupied, it means that previous sync is still running.
#* We need to be careful when we extend the sync period dynamically.
fields.summary: Long running synchronization initiation blocks subsequent scheduled syncs and other scheduled tasks
